A good example of the dangers of e-cigarettes is diacetyl. It's an artificial flavoring used in microwave popcorn to make it extra buttery. It's been known for decades that it's extremely harmful to inhale. They've even named the disease it causes "popcorn lung". There are still many companies that use diacetyl in their e-liquids/flavoring. About a decade ago I contacted many e-liquid makers about them selling buttery popcorn flavorings (because they all contained diacetyl)... but only one company ever responded and stopped using it as an ingredient in their products. You'd think that they would want to refrain from having chemicals that are Known to be very dangerous/harmful to lungs... but it seems like they just didn't/don't care. Companies today still sell "buttery popcorn" and other flavors that contain diacetyl.

Although it's likely that most e-liquids/e-cigs are safer to vape than smoking, it's very possible that many of them contain extremely dangerous and harmful ingredients. Most flavors used were made to be eaten, not inhaled and we do not know which one's will cause sickness and which one's won't. It's an experiment... and it's not going to be easy to figure out which specific chemicals are causing sickness, because there are just too many to sort through.

EVALI has had some weird patterns, I think. I became interested in this subject because a number of the symptoms were the same as devastating (presumed) viruses that caused outbreaks in my geographical area. Our doctors called these monsters "unknown" "really tough" viruses. The basic trajectory was onset of mild respiratory illness followed by terrible intestinal symptoms about 48 hours later. I do not think ARDS was part of the profile. It seemed more elderly people died. A significant number of people were permanently damaged, basically with ME/CFS. The people I know who were victims, were never vapers though some smoked tobacco.

One report claimed the first EVALI case was in a man in his 60's who did not use THC, who had used nicotine vapes from legitimate sources, for many years after stopping smoking.

The original geographic patterns for EVALI seemed to show clusters of the illness. I wondered if an infectious agent was adding to the disorder. Young people I know who vape, frequently share vapes and inhale deeply.

It seemed to me that adulterated product would have had a wider distribution, for instance over a geographic area of distribution, rather than small cluster groups.

For quite a while, it was reported that all of the EVALI cases were in the US. Eventually there were some cases in Canada and the Caribbean. Today's video is the first time I have heard of cases in Europe. If adulterated product is the cause, is there a distribution network that mainly or only services the U.S.?

Then science seemed to name vitamin E acetate + TCH, both of which could point to illicit manufacture. Then COVID came and i wondered if EVALI cases were early COVID. Research indicates that SARS-CoV2 was circulating at least much earlier in 2019 than has been thought.

Of more interest to me is if part of EVALI causation might be an as yet unidentified virus.

The good thing i think we will get from COVID is that doctors and researchers are paying attention to those with "Long COVID". Prior to this, folks who failed to recover from a viral infection in a maximum of 21 days, were discarded into the human garbage dump of psychiatry. At least that is what happened to those who were stupid enough to continue to complain of illness. The smart ones shut up, did the best they could, some until they could no longer work, at which time they began protracted battles for disability status.

All of this is anecdotal and my reasoning may be faulty. There seem to be "unknown" "really tough" viruses that do terrible things to people, and which science cannot detect. Might there be a viral component to EVALI? Has enough research been done to rule out a stealthy virus as part of the cause of EVALI? Or the reactivation of latent viruses such as Herpes viruses?

I love your show and usually you are spot on, but on this episode, you are way off base. E-cigarette use propylene glycol and glycerol. They are water soluble and get absorbed into your blood stream, which clears the lungs of these compounds.  They are food additives with a proven safety record when absorbed into the blood stream. When it comes to marijuana vapes, the manufacturers were using approved hemp terpenes as a diluent, a liquid used to dilute the THC resin, but those cost over $1,000 per gallon. In mid 2019, some shady manufacturers started using vitamin E acetate, which only costs $20 per gallon and is an oil that is not water soluble, which means it coats the airways in your lungs in a thin film of oil, that prevents oxygen transfer and does not get absorbed into the blood stream. In the second half of 2019, people started getting sick and the sellers of vitamin E acetate as a diluent quickly stopped selling their products, with their websites quickly disappearing. By November 2019, it was widely known that vitamin E acetate was the culprit and the incidence of EVALI rapidly started to decline. By the time that Covid hit, in March and April of 2020, the only people that were getting EVALI were people that were using old products, or underground THC vape manufactures that still had vitamin E on hand and had not gotten the memo. By mid 2020, EVALI was pretty much a thing of the past. To recap, people that were in the pipeline to use terpene based products, ie THC vapes, were the only people that could get the adulterated vitamin E acetate. People that use e-cigarette were only getting propylene glycol and glycerol and did not get this disease. And the disease is pretty much a thing of the past. 2019 and 2020? Yes. In 2022? Absolutely not.

"EVALI" is caused by illicit-market THC Cartridges made using various additives that AREN'T Safe to vape, such as Vitamin E Acetate, which when heated in a cartridge can break down into things like acetic acid

"Limonene" is mentioned, Limonene is an aromatic cannabis terpene produced in the flower's resin glands, this is ALSO something found in THC Carts, as terpene extracts are used as flavorants/odorants to make them more palatable. Terpene extracts are NOT typically used in mainstream e-liquids as we have significantly safer and more flavorful options. Though we do generally recommend avoiding citric flavors, cinnamon, etc. as those flavorings are known to be among the "more harmful" ones by nature (Though more harmful in this case is still some 95-99% safer than smoking cigarettes, according to a lot of studies. Look up the royal college of physicians and the UK vape regulations if you want some very good info on nicotine-based vaping)

This "Cross-contamination" Or muddling of the message comes about because "Vaping" is a delivery method shared by nicotine vape, thc vape, nebulizers, etc. If you stick to known brands and a reputable shop or source for nicotine-based vape systems (Specifically OPEN systems, where you have to refill it with liquid yourself, not disposable devices or pre-filled systems) as a smoking alternative, you should be 100% Fine as long as you stay within your devices specs.
